message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Argumentative XAI: A Survey
Paper Abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) has been investigated for decades and, together with AI itself, has witnessed unprecedented growth in recent years. Among various approaches to XAI, argumentative models have been advocated in both the AI and social science literature, as their dialectical nature appears to match some basic desirable features of the explanation activity. In this survey we overview XAI approaches built using methods from the field of computational argumentation, leveraging its wide array of reasoning abstractions and explanation delivery methods. We overview the literature focusing on different types of explanation (intrinsic and post-hoc), different models with which argumentation-based explanations are deployed, different forms of delivery, and different argumentation frameworks they use. We also lay out a roadmap for future work.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Explainable artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explainable_Artificial_Intelligence"},{"title":"File:Ethics of AI in Digital Medicine – Explanation why transparent explainable AI is important.webm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ethics_of_AI_in_Digital_Medicine_%E2%80%93_Explanation_why_transparent_explainable_AI_is_important.webm"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Latifa Al-Abdulkarim - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latifa_Al-Abdulkarim"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_engineering"},{"title":"Partnership on AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partnership_on_AI"},{"title":"Machine Learning and Knowledge Extraction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_Learning_and_Knowledge_Extraction"},{"title":"David Ferrucci - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Ferrucci"}]

Here are the search results for "Explainable AI":

## Overview

Explainable AI (XAI), often overlapping with interpretable AI or explainable machine learning (XML), is a field of research that explores methods that provide humans with the ability of intellectual oversight over AI algorithms.

## Purpose and Goals

XAI aims to explain what has been done, what is being done, and what will be done next, and to unveil which information these actions are based on.(no content)XAI can improve the user experience of a product or service by helping end users trust that the AI is making good decisions.

## Key Principles

XAI algorithms follow the three principles of transparency, interpretability, and explainability.(no content)Interpretability refers to the user's ability to understand model outputs, while Model Transparency includes Simulatability (reproducibility of predictions), Decomposability (intuitive explanations for parameters), and Algorithmic Transparency (explaining how algorithms work).

## Importance in Critical Domains

XAI is especially important in domains like medicine, defense, finance, and law, where it is crucial to understand decisions and build trust in the algorithms.

## Technical Approaches

DARPA established the XAI program in 2014 to try to solve transparency problems.(no content)SHAP enables visualizing the contribution of each feature to the output, and LIME can locally approximate a model's outputs with a simpler, interpretable model.

Links: [{"title":"Explainable artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explainable_Artificial_Intelligence"},{"title":"File:Ethics of AI in Digital Medicine – Explanation why transparent explainable AI is important.webm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ethics_of_AI_in_Digital_Medicine_%E2%80%93_Explanation_why_transparent_explainable_AI_is_important.webm"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Latifa Al-Abdulkarim - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latifa_Al-Abdulkarim"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_engineering"},{"title":"Partnership on AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partnership_on_AI"},{"title":"Machine Learning and Knowledge Extraction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_Learning_and_Knowledge_Extraction"},{"title":"David Ferrucci - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Ferrucci"}]

Here are the search results for "Explainable AI":

## Overview

Explainable AI (XAI), often overlapping with interpretable AI or explainable machine learning (XML), is a field of research that explores methods that provide humans with the ability of intellectual oversight over AI algorithms.

## Purpose and Goals

XAI aims to explain what has been done, what is being done, and what will be done next, and to unveil which information these actions are based on.(no content)XAI can improve the user experience of a product or service by helping end users trust that the AI is making good decisions.

## Key Principles

XAI algorithms follow the three principles of transparency, interpretability, and explainability.(no content)Interpretability refers to the user's ability to understand model outputs, while Model Transparency includes Simulatability (reproducibility of predictions), Decomposability (intuitive explanations for parameters), and Algorithmic Transparency (explaining how algorithms work).

## Importance in Critical Domains

XAI is especially important in domains like medicine, defense, finance, and law, where it is crucial to understand decisions and build trust in the algorithms.

## Technical Approaches

DARPA established the XAI program in 2014 to try to solve transparency problems.(no content)SHAP enables visualizing the contribution of each feature to the output, and LIME can locally approximate a model's outputs with a simpler, interpretable model.

Web search results for query: "Argumentation framework"

Links: [{"title":"Argumentation framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_framework"},{"title":"Argumentation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_theory"},{"title":"Logic of argumentation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_of_argumentation"},{"title":"Probabilistic argumentation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_argumentation"},{"title":"Practical arguments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Practical_arguments"},{"title":"Argüman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arg%C3%BCman"},{"title":"Kialo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kialo"},{"title":"Argument technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_technology"},{"title":"Argumentation scheme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_scheme"},{"title":"Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about argumentation frameworks:

## Overview

In artificial intelligence and related fields, an argumentation framework is a way to deal with contentious information and draw conclusions from it using formalized arguments.

## Types of Argumentation Frameworks

**Abstract Argumentation Frameworks:**
In an abstract argumentation framework, entry-level information is a set of abstract arguments.

**Logic-Based Argumentation:**
In logic-based argumentation frameworks, an argument is not an abstract entity, but a pair, where the first part is a minimal consistent set of formulae enough to prove the formula for the second part of the argument.(no content)One can build a graph and reason in a similar way to the abstract argumentation frameworks, with the difference that the information inferred from a logic-based argumentation framework is a set of formulae (the consequences of the accepted arguments).

**Probabilistic Argumentation:**
Probabilistic argumentation refers to different formal frameworks pertaining to probabilistic logic, sharing the idea that qualitative aspects can be captured by an underlying logic, while quantitative aspects of uncertainty can be accounted for by probabilistic measures.

## Applications and Significance

In the 1980s and 1990s, philosophical theories of arguments were leveraged to handle key computational challenges, such as modeling non-monotonic and defeasible reasoning, and mechanisms for computing semantics of argumentation frameworks were introduced as a way of providing a calculus of opposition for computing what is reasonable to believe in the context of conflicting arguments.

I've completed a web search for "Model interpretation machine learning." Here are the key findings:

## What is Model Interpretation?

Model interpretability describes the possibility of comprehending the ML model and presenting the underlying basis for decision-making in a way that is understandable to humans.

## Explainable AI and Interpretable AI

Explainable AI (XAI), or Interpretable AI, or Explainable Machine Learning (XML), is artificial intelligence (AI) in which humans can understand the decisions or predictions made by the AI.(no content)It contrasts with the "black box" concept in machine learning where even its designers cannot explain why an AI arrived at a specific decision.

## Key Approaches

The search results reveal several approaches to model interpretation:

1. **White-box vs. Black-box Models**: Machine learning algorithms used in AI can be categorized as white-box or black-box. White-box models provide results that are understandable to experts in the domain. Black-box models, on the other hand, are extremely hard to explain and may not be understood even by domain experts.

2. **Mechanistic Interpretability**: Mechanistic interpretability is a subfield of research within explainable artificial intelligence that aims to understand the internal workings of neural networks by analyzing the mechanisms present in their computations.

3. **XAI Principles**: XAI algorithms follow the three principles of transparency, interpretability, and explainability.

Model interpretation is increasingly important in domains where understanding AI decisions is critical, such as medicine, finance, and law.

Web search results for query: "Computational argumentation"

Links: [{"title":"Argumentation framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_framework"},{"title":"Argumentation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_theory"},{"title":"Argument technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_technology"},{"title":"Argumentation scheme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_scheme"},{"title":"Argument mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_mining"},{"title":"Logic of argumentation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_of_argumentation"},{"title":"Argument - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument"},{"title":"Katie Atkinson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katie_Atkinson"},{"title":"Argument (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Computational theory of mind - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_theory_of_mind"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of computational argumentation:

## Definition

Efforts have been made within the field of artificial intelligence to perform and analyze argumentation with computers.(no content)Argument technology is a sub-field of collective intelligence and artificial intelligence that focuses on applying computational techniques to the creation, identification, analysis, navigation, evaluation and visualisation of arguments and debates.

## Key Components

**Argumentation Frameworks**: An argumentation framework is a way to deal with contentious information and draw conclusions from it using formalized arguments.(no content)An argumentation framework is represented with a directed graph such that the nodes are the arguments, and the arrows represent the attack relation.

**Argument Mining**: Argument mining, or argumentation mining, is a research area within the natural-language processing field. The goal of argument mining is the automatic extraction and identification of argumentative structures from natural language text with the aid of computer programs.

## Applications

Computational argumentation systems have found particular application in domains where formal logic and classical decision theory are unable to capture the richness of reasoning, domains such as law and medicine. Additional applications include argument search engines that return a list of arguments for and against a topic to support informed decision-making or to help debaters prepare for debates.

## Field Development

The area has been supported by various dedicated events such as the International Workshop on Computational Models of Natural Argument (CMNA) which has run annually since 2001; the International Workshop on Argument in Multi Agent Systems (ArgMAS) annually since 2004; the Workshop on Argument Mining, annually since 2014, and the Conference on Computational Models of Argument (COMMA), biennially since 2006.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Argumentation framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_framework"},{"title":"Argumentation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_theory"},{"title":"Argument technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_technology"},{"title":"Argumentation scheme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_scheme"},{"title":"Argument mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_mining"},{"title":"Logic of argumentation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_of_argumentation"},{"title":"Argument - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument"},{"title":"Katie Atkinson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katie_Atkinson"},{"title":"Argument (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Computational theory of mind - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_theory_of_mind"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of computational argumentation:

## Definition

Efforts have been made within the field of artificial intelligence to perform and analyze argumentation with computers.(no content)Argument technology is a sub-field of collective intelligence and artificial intelligence that focuses on applying computational techniques to the creation, identification, analysis, navigation, evaluation and visualisation of arguments and debates.

## Key Components

**Argumentation Frameworks**: An argumentation framework is a way to deal with contentious information and draw conclusions from it using formalized arguments.(no content)An argumentation framework is represented with a directed graph such that the nodes are the arguments, and the arrows represent the attack relation.

**Argument Mining**: Argument mining, or argumentation mining, is a research area within the natural-language processing field. The goal of argument mining is the automatic extraction and identification of argumentative structures from natural language text with the aid of computer programs.

## Applications

Computational argumentation systems have found particular application in domains where formal logic and classical decision theory are unable to capture the richness of reasoning, domains such as law and medicine. Additional applications include argument search engines that return a list of arguments for and against a topic to support informed decision-making or to help debaters prepare for debates.

## Field Development

The area has been supported by various dedicated events such as the International Workshop on Computational Models of Natural Argument (CMNA) which has run annually since 2001; the International Workshop on Argument in Multi Agent Systems (ArgMAS) annually since 2004; the Workshop on Argument Mining, annually since 2014, and the Conference on Computational Models of Argument (COMMA), biennially since 2006.

Web search results for query: "Artificial Intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

I've completed the web search for "Artificial Intelligence" and found comprehensive information from multiple sources. Here's an overview of what the search returned:

## Key Findings

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

**History:** Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

**Goals and Approaches:** The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics. To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

**Current Development:** Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

**Applications:** The search results show AI is being used in diverse fields including military applications, astronomy, healthcare, media analysis, video games, music composition, and art creation.

**Challenges:** The ethics of artificial intelligence covers a broad range of topics within AI that are considered to have particular ethical stakes. This includes algorithmic biases, fairness, accountability, transparency, privacy, and regulation, particularly where systems influence or automate human decision-making.
